title: 110_hr4847
content: The Act is titled the "United States Fire Administration Reauthorization Act of 2008". Congress finds that the United States still has one of the highest fire death rates in the industrialized world, with 3,245 civilian fire deaths reported in 2006. Over 100 firefighters die in the line of duty each year, and efforts should be made to reduce these fatalities. Collaboration within the fire service community is essential to promote national voluntary consensus standards for firefighter safety. The United States Fire Administration plays a crucial role in this endeavor. The United States Fire Administration supports fire departments through training, data collection, and research to improve fire prevention and suppression technologies. Data collection on fire incidents is crucial for policymakers and responders to address emerging hazards. Research by government and non-government organizations advances fire technologies. The United States Fire Administration plays a key role in advancing fire prevention and suppression technologies, representing the fire service within the Federal Government. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to authorize appropriations for the United States Fire Administration, with specific funding amounts allocated for fiscal years 2009 to 2012. Additionally, modifications and reports are required for the National Fire Academy training program. Amendments to the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 include updates to the training at the Fire Academy, focusing on response tactics for national catastrophes and incidents involving weapons of mass destruction. The amendments to the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 include updates to training at the Fire Academy, focusing on response tactics for national catastrophes and incidents involving weapons of mass destruction. Additionally, the amendments address response tactics for fighting large-scale fires, fires at the wildland-urban interface, fires involving hazardous materials, and advanced emergency medical services training. The Administrator is required to report changes to the Academy curriculum, including the basis for these changes and the desired training outcomes. Additionally, the Administrator is authorized to enter into contracts for on-site training through accredited organizations. The Administrator is authorized to provide assistance to State and local fire service training programs through grants, contracts, or other means. They can also enter into contracts with nationally recognized organizations for on-site training programs that meet national standards for fire service personnel. The Administrator can provide assistance to State and local fire service training programs through contracts with organizations that offer accredited training leading to certification or through cooperative agreements with Federal agencies. The funds allocated for this purpose cannot exceed 4 percent of the total authorized amount in a fiscal year. The Administrator of the United States Fire Administration, in consultation with the National Academy for Fire Prevention and Control, must integrate a course on incident command training for fire service personnel at ports and marine environments within 2 years of this Act. The course will cover fighting fires on water and vessels, excluding border and port security. SEC. 5. NATIONAL FIRE INCIDENT REPORTING SYSTEM UPGRADES. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to allocate $5,000,000 for updating the National Fire Incident Reporting System to an Internet-based, real-time database. Additionally, a technical correction is made to include Federal assistance in addition to State assistance. SEC. 6. FIRE TECHNOLOGY ASSISTANCE AND DISSEMINATION. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to provide assistance for fire prevention and control in the wildland-urban interface. The Administrator is authorized to assist fire services for activities and equipment in this area. Additionally, a new subsection is added for dissemination of information related to fire prevention and control. Beginning 1 year after the enactment of the United States Fire Administration Reauthorization Act of 2008, the Administrator will collaborate with relevant government departments to provide public access to information on firefighting activities funded by the United States Fire Administration through an Internet database. SEC. 7 of the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to promote adoption of national standards for firefighter health and safety. This includes standards for operations, training, staffing, and fitness. The Administrator will educate fire services on these standards and encourage their adoption at all government levels. Additionally, SEC. 38 focuses on training agencies about the importance of clearing biomass in wildland areas to enhance firefighter safety. The Administrator will develop and provide information and training to relevant federal departments on clearing biomass in wildland areas for firefighter safety. The Administrator will coordinate fire prevention and control programs by utilizing existing resources and liaising with State and local government agencies, as well as private and other Federal organizations. The Administrator will provide liaison to coordinate fire service-based emergency medical services programs with State and local government agencies, private, and other Federal organizations. The Administrator is authorized to conduct studies on fire service-based emergency medical services, including protocols for on-scene care, resource allocation, and training requirements. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. In Section 9 of the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974, definitions are provided. Section 4 of the Act is amended to include new definitions such as 'hazardous materials' and 'wildland-urban interface'. The term 'wildland-urban interface' is defined in the Healthy Forests Restoration Act of 2003. Congress supports the adoption of fire sprinklers in commercial, educational, and residential buildings as recommended by the United States Fire Administration. The House of Representatives passed this support on April 3, 2008.
